problem: Prove by induction that for all positive integers n, the sum of the first n positive integers equals n(n+1)/2.
If p → q is true, and q → r is true, what can be concluded about p → r? Prove your answer.

Consider the statement: 'If it is raining, then the ground is wet.' Write the contrapositive, converse, and inverse of this statement, and determine which ones are logically equivalent to the original statement.
Prove that for any sets A, B, and C, we have (A ∩ B) ∪ (A ∩ C) = A ∩ (B ∪ C).
Using proof by contradiction, prove that √2 is irrational.
Prove that if n² is even, then n is even.
Determine whether the following argument is valid: 'If I study, I will pass the exam. I passed the exam. Therefore, I studied.'
Construct a truth table for the statement (p → q) ∧ (¬q → ¬p) and determine if it is a tautology.
Prove by direct proof that the sum of two consecutive integers is odd.
Let P(n) be the statement that 1³ + 2³ + ... + n³ = (n(n+1)/2)² for the positive integer n. Prove that P(n) is true for all positive integers n.
If ¬(p ∧ q) is true, what can you conclude about p and q? Justify your answer using logical equivalences.
Use mathematical induction to prove that n! > 2ⁿ for all integers n ≥ 4.
Prove or disprove: For all sets A, B, and C, if A ⊆ B and B ⊆ C, then A ⊆ C.
Express the following statement using quantifiers and logical symbols: 'Some integers are both even and greater than 10.'
Prove that the square of any odd integer is of the form 8k + 1 for some integer k.
Find the negation of the statement: 'For all real numbers x, if x² > 4, then x > 2 or x < -2.'
Prove that for any sets A and B, (A ∪ B)' = A' ∩ B' using the laws of logic (where X' represents the complement of set X).

Determine whether the following argument is valid: 'If x is divisible by 6, then x is divisible by 2 and x is divisible by 3. x is divisible by 2 and x is divisible by 3. Therefore, x is divisible by 6.'
Prove by cases: For any integer n, the value of n² - n + 41 is never divisible by 41.
Show that the statement p → (q → r) is logically equivalent to (p ∧ q) → r.
Prove by contradiction: There are infinitely many prime numbers.
Use the principle of mathematical induction to prove that for all positive integers n, 2ⁿ > n.
Determine the truth value of the statement: 'For all positive integers n, n² ≥ n.'
Prove that the statement (p → q) → p is not a tautology.
Examine the following argument: 'If it is sunny, then we go to the beach. If we go to the beach, then we swim. We did not swim. Therefore, it was not sunny.' Is this argument valid? Explain.
Prove that for any integers a and b, if a² + b² is odd, then exactly one of a or b is odd.
Use the well-ordering principle to prove that every positive integer can be expressed as a product of prime numbers.
Prove that for any sets A, B, and C, we have A - (B ∩ C) = (A - B) ∪ (A - C).
Determine whether the following is a valid argument by constructing a truth table: 'If p, then q. If not p, then r. If q, then s. Therefore, if not r, then s.'
Prove that if n is a positive integer, then n is a perfect square if and only if the number of its divisors is odd.
A cube is painted red on all faces and then cut into 27 equal smaller cubes. How many of these smaller cubes have exactly two red faces?

If you fold a square piece of paper in half vertically, then fold it in half horizontally, and then cut off the bottom-right corner of the folded paper, how many holes will the paper have when unfolded?
A rectangular prism has dimensions 3×4×5. A plane cuts through the prism passing through the center of the prism and parallel to one of the faces. What is the area of the resulting cross-section?

Four identical cubes are arranged in a 2×2 grid. If you view this arrangement from directly above, from the front, and from the right side, what is the maximum number of cubes that could appear to be visible from all three perspectives combined?
A cylindrical hole of radius 2 cm is drilled through the center of a sphere of radius 5 cm. What is the volume of the remaining portion of the sphere?
A triangular pyramid has an equilateral triangle as its base with side length 6 cm. If all three edges from the apex to the base vertices have length 8 cm, what is the height of the pyramid?

A cube with edge length 4 cm is cut by a plane that passes through two diagonally opposite vertices of the cube and through the midpoints of two edges that do not contain either of those vertices. What is the area of the resulting cross-section?
A regular octahedron has all edges of length 4 cm. What is the distance between two opposite vertices of the octahedron?
Three unit cubes are arranged in an L-shape (like a 3D Tetris piece). What is the minimum number of additional unit cubes needed to complete a 2×2×2 cube?
A right circular cone with height 12 cm and base radius 5 cm is cut by a plane parallel to the base at a height of 8 cm from the base. What is the radius of the resulting circular cross-section?
A 3×3×3 cube is built from 27 unit cubes. If the large cube is dipped in paint so that all the exterior faces are painted, how many of the small unit cubes have exactly two painted faces?
A rectangular sheet of paper has dimensions 8×11. If you fold the paper so that one corner touches the opposite corner, what is the length of the crease formed?

A right circular cylinder with radius 3 cm and height 8 cm is cut by a plane that passes through a diameter of the top face and is tangent to the bottom face. What is the area of the resulting cross-section?
If you have a cube with side length 2, what is the maximum number of non-overlapping spheres of radius 0.5 that can fit inside the cube?
A tetrahedron has vertices at points (0,0,0), (1,0,0), (0,1,0), and (0,0,1). If a plane cuts this tetrahedron parallel to the xy-plane at z = 0.5, what is the area of the resulting cross-section?
A rectangular box has dimensions 4×6×8. Find the length of the longest straight line that can be drawn from one vertex of the box to another vertex.
A square pyramid has a base with side length 10 cm and a height of 12 cm. What is the area of a cross-section formed by a plane that is parallel to the base and 4 cm above it?
If you rotate a 30-60-90 triangle around its shortest side, what 3D shape is formed and what is its volume if the shortest side has length 4?

A 4×4×4 cube is made up of 64 unit cubes. If the large cube is carved out so that all cubes that share a face, edge, or corner with the center of the large cube are removed, how many unit cubes remain?
An ant is at one vertex of a cube with side length 1. What is the shortest distance the ant must crawl along the surface of the cube to reach the opposite vertex?
If you draw all diagonals of a regular hexagon, how many triangles are formed in total (counting all triangles of any size)?
A solid wooden cube with side length 10 cm has a cylindrical hole of diameter 6 cm drilled through the center of the cube perpendicular to one of the faces. What is the volume of the remaining wood?
A regular octahedron has all edges of length 4 units. What is the volume of the octahedron?

Two cubes with side lengths 3 cm and 5 cm are positioned so that one vertex of each cube coincides, and corresponding edges from this vertex are aligned along the same lines. What is the volume of the intersection of the two cubes?
A semicircle with diameter 8 cm is revolved around its diameter. What is the volume of the resulting 3D shape?
Three circles with radii 3, 4, and 5 are placed so that each circle is externally tangent to the other two. What is the area of the region enclosed by the three circles?

A ladder 10 meters long leans against a vertical wall with its base 6 meters from the wall. If the top of the ladder slips down 2 meters, how far will the bottom of the ladder slide away from the wall?
A rectangular sheet of paper ABCD has dimensions 6×8. The sheet is folded so that corner A touches the midpoint of side CD. What is the length of the crease formed by this fold?
A solid sphere of radius 5 cm has a mass of 500 grams. A cylindrical hole with radius 2 cm is drilled through the center of the sphere. What is the mass of the remaining solid?
An ant starts at one corner of a cube and wants to reach the opposite corner. If the ant can only walk along the edges of the cube, what is the minimum number of edges the ant must traverse?
If all brontles are climpets, and no climpets are dorqs, which of the following must be true? A) Some brontles are dorqs B) No brontles are dorqs C) All dorqs are brontles D) Some dorqs are brontles
Consider the statements: 'If Rose wins the competition, then either Sam or Terry will be upset.' 'Sam is not upset.' What can be logically concluded?
Complete the analogy: Glacier is to Ice as Forest is to ____
Statement 1: All lawyers are logical thinkers. Statement 2: Some doctors are lawyers. What can you conclude with certainty?
If 'No heroes are cowards' and 'All soldiers are heroes' are both true, what must be true about the relationship between soldiers and cowards?
Complete the analogy: Democracy is to Monarchy as Many is to ____
If it is false that 'Either John is not present or Mary is late', what must be true?
Consider these statements: 'If I study, I pass the exam.' 'I did not pass the exam.' What can you conclude?
Complete the sequence: Calf is to Cow as Fawn is to ____
If 'All A are B' and 'Some C are not B', which conclusion is valid? A) Some A are C B) Some C are not A C) No C are A D) Some A are not C

If the statement 'If it rains, then the game is canceled' is true, which of the following must also be true? A) If it doesn't rain, then the game isn't canceled B) If the game is canceled, then it rained C) If the game isn't canceled, then it didn't rain D) None of the above
Frame is to Picture as ____ is to Story
Given: 'No mammals are cold-blooded.' 'Some aquatic animals are cold-blooded.' What can you conclude about the relationship between mammals and aquatic animals?

If 'Only creative people are successful artists' is true, which statement must also be true? A) All creative people are successful artists B) Some creative people are successful artists C) All successful artists are creative people D) Some successful artists are not creative people
Enigma is to Mystery as Euphoria is to ____
Given: 'If the temperature rises, the snow will melt.' 'The snow did not melt.' What can you conclude?
Either Jennifer or Michael is telling the truth, but not both. If Jennifer says, 'Michael is lying,' what is the truth status of Michael's statement?
Sycophant is to Flattery as Misanthrope is to ____
If all X are Y, and some Z are not Y, which of the following must be true? A) All X are Z B) No X are Z C) Some Z are not X D) Some X are Z
Consider: 'All authors are readers.' 'Some critics are not readers.' What can you conclude about the relationship between authors and critics?
Kangaroo is to Joey as Eagle is to ____

Which statement is logically equivalent to 'If I am not tired, then I will go running'? A) If I am tired, then I will not go running B) If I go running, then I am not tired C) If I don't go running, then I am tired D) If I am tired, then I will go running
If I state, 'It is not the case that either I own a car or I don't use public transportation,' what must be true?
Audacious is to Timid as Garrulous is to ____
Given these premises: 'All birds have feathers.' 'No reptiles have feathers.' What can you conclude about birds and reptiles?

If 'Some athletes are not swimmers' and 'All swimmers are fit,' which conclusion is valid? A) Some athletes are fit B) All fit people are athletes C) Some fit people are not athletes D) Some athletes are not fit
Consider this statement: 'If it is raining, then the streets are wet.' If the streets are not wet, what can you conclude?
Pandemic is to Disease as Tsunami is to ____
If 'No honest people are thieves' and 'Some politicians are honest,' what can you conclude about the relationship between politicians and thieves?

Three people (Alex, Blake, and Casey) each make one statement: Alex: 'Blake is lying.' Blake: 'Casey is lying.' Casey: 'Alex and Blake are both lying.' If exactly one person is telling the truth, who is it?
What is the next number in this sequence? 1, 4, 9, 16, 25, 36, ...
What letter should come next in this sequence? D, H, L, P, ...
Find the next three terms in the sequence: 3, 1, 4, 1, 5, 9, 2, 6, ...
What number replaces the question mark? 2, 3, 5, 8, 13, ?

1

What are the next two letters in this pattern? A, C, F, J, O, ...

What number should replace the question mark? 0, 1, 1, 2, 3, 5, 8, 13, 21, ?

What are the next two numbers in this sequence? 1, 2, 4, 7, 11, 16, ...
Find the missing number: 1, 3, 7, 15, 31, ?

What number completes this sequence? 4, 5, 8, 17, 44, ?
Find the next number: 2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, ...

Complete the pattern: 2, 6, 18, 54, ...
What are the next three letters in this sequence? A, A, B, C, E, H, ...
Find the next number: 1, 4, 7, 10, 13, ...
What are the next two symbols in this pattern? ↑, →, ↓, ←, ↑, →, ...

A man lives on the 10th floor of a building. Every morning he takes the elevator down to the ground floor to go to work. When he returns in the evening, he takes the elevator to the 7th floor and walks up the stairs for the remaining floors. However, on rainy days, he takes the elevator all the way to the 10th floor. Why?
A woman has two sons who were born on the same day of the same month of the same year to the same mother and father, but they are not twins. How is this possible?
A man is found dead in the middle of the desert with a backpack on. What happened?

You're standing outside a room with no windows. The room has three light bulbs inside, and there are three switches outside the room. Each switch controls one light bulb. If you can only enter the room once, how can you determine which switch controls which light bulb?
A man walks into a bar and asks for a glass of water. The bartender pulls out a gun and points it at him. The man says 'Thank you' and leaves. Why?

In a room there are 1000 light bulbs labeled from 1 to 1000. Initially, all of them are off. You perform 1000 steps. In the first step, you toggle all the bulbs. In the second step, you toggle bulbs 2, 4, 6, ... (all even-labeled bulbs). In the third step, you toggle bulbs 3, 6, 9, ... (every third bulb). In the fourth step, you toggle bulbs 4, 8, 12, ... (every fourth bulb). You continue this pattern until the 1000th step, when you toggle only bulb 1000. Which bulbs are on after all 1000 steps?
Two pieces of rope burn at inconsistent rates. Each piece takes exactly one hour to burn completely. How can you measure 45 minutes using only these two ropes and a lighter?

A man lives in a high-rise apartment building. One day, he comes home, gets into the elevator, and, if there is someone else in the elevator or if it is raining, he goes to his floor directly. Otherwise, he goes to the 7th floor and walks the rest of the way up. Why?
Without lifting your pen from the paper, can you draw four straight lines that pass through all nine dots arranged in a 3x3 grid?

A murderer is condemned to death. He has to choose between three rooms. The first is full of raging fires, the second is full of assassins with loaded guns, and the third is full of lions that haven't eaten in 3 years. Which room is safest for him?

There is a sealed metal box with no openings, no seams, and no way to see inside. Inside the box is a single penny. How do you determine if the penny is heads up or tails up without opening the box in any way?

A man is found dead in his office with a cassette tape in his hand and a gun on the floor. When the police arrive, they press play on the cassette player on the desk. They hear the man say, 'I can't go on. I have nothing to live for.' followed by the sound of a gunshot. The police immediately know that the man was murdered. How did they know?

A father and his son are in a car accident. The father dies on the scene, but the son is rushed to the hospital. At the hospital, the surgeon looks at the boy and says, 'I can't operate on this boy, he's my son.' How can this be?
A prisoner is told, 'If you tell a lie, we will hang you; if you tell the truth, we will shoot you.' What can the prisoner say to save himself?
A man is trapped in a sealed, windowless, concrete room. All he has with him is a wood table and a handheld mirror. How does he escape?
You have 8 balls that are identical in appearance, but one is slightly heavier than the rest. Using a balance scale, how can you identify the heavier ball with just 2 weighings?

A magician claimed he could throw a ping pong ball so that it would go a short distance, come to a complete stop, and then reverse direction - all without touching any walls or objects and without the ball being touched by anything else. How is this possible?
You have a cake that needs to be cut into exactly 8 equal pieces. How can you do this with just 3 straight cuts?

A man is found dead on a Sunday morning. His wife calls the police immediately. The police question the wife and the staff and get these alibis: The wife was sleeping, the cook was cooking breakfast, the gardener was picking vegetables, the maid was getting the mail, and the butler was cleaning the closet. The police immediately arrested the murderer. Who did it?

There are 100 doors in a row, all initially closed. You make 100 passes by the doors. In the first pass, you toggle every door (if the door is closed, you open it; if it's open, you close it). In the second pass, you toggle every second door (doors 2, 4, 6, ...). In the third pass, you toggle every third door (doors 3, 6, 9, ...). Continue this pattern until you complete the 100th pass, in which you toggle only door 100. After all 100 passes, which doors are open?
A girl who was just learning to drive went down a one-way street in the wrong direction, but did not break the law. How is this possible?
Two mothers and two daughters went out for dinner. Everyone ate one burger, yet they only ate three burgers in total. How is this possible?

You have 10 balls of identical appearance, and a scale that can only tell you which side of the scale is heavier (not by how much). If exactly one ball is heavier than the rest, how can you determine which one it is with just three weighings?

A hunter leaves his cabin early in the morning and walks 1 mile due south. Then he turns and walks 1 mile due east. There he shoots a bear. Then he turns again and walks 1 mile due north, at which point he is back at his cabin. What color is the bear and why?

A woman gives a beggar 100 coins. The beggar already has some coins. After the woman leaves, the beggar discovers that if he divides his total number of coins into unequal piles, one pile will have twice as many coins as the other pile. How many coins did the beggar have before the woman gave him 100 more?
You have two hourglasses: one measures 7 minutes and the other measures 11 minutes. Using only these two hourglasses, how can you measure exactly 15 minutes?
A woman walks into a room with a match, a kerosene lamp, a candle, and a fireplace. What should she light first?

A man is trapped in a room with only two exit doors. Behind Door A is a room filled with a blazing fire that will kill the man. Behind Door B are three deadly assassins waiting to kill the man. How does the man escape safely?

There is a box with a hole in it. The hole is 3 inches in diameter. Inside the box is a golf ball that is 1.5 inches in diameter. Without opening the box, how can you get the golf ball out of the box?
A man pushes his car to a hotel and tells its owner he's bankrupt. Why?

A city implemented a new traffic light system at its busiest intersection. After installation, accidents decreased by 30%. The city council claims this proves the new system caused the reduction in accidents. What alternative explanations might exist for this correlation?

A researcher finds that children who eat breakfast perform better on morning tests than those who don't. She concludes that breakfast consumption causes improved cognitive performance. What confounding variables might be influencing this relationship?

A company notices that employees who participate in its optional wellness program have fewer sick days. The CEO wants to make the program mandatory to reduce absenteeism. Explain why this logic might be flawed from a causal reasoning perspective.

Ice cream sales and drowning deaths both increase during summer months. A newspaper headline claims 'Ice Cream Sales Linked to Drowning Deaths.' What is the error in causal reasoning here, and what is the more likely explanation?
A study found that people who sleep with their shoes on tend to wake up with headaches. What's wrong with concluding that sleeping with shoes causes headaches?

After implementing a strict attendance policy, a school sees improved test scores. The principal attributes the improvement to the policy. Identify three alternative explanations that might account for this outcome.

In a factory, Machine A breaks down, then Machine B breaks down, then Machine C breaks down. A technician claims Machine A's failure caused the cascade of breakdowns. What evidence would you need to evaluate this causal claim?

A marketing study shows that people who view a product advertisement are more likely to purchase the product than those who don't. What's problematic about concluding the advertisement caused the increased purchases?

A farmer notices that fields treated with a new fertilizer produce higher yields than untreated fields. However, the treated fields are also closer to a water source. How does this complicate the causal relationship between fertilizer and yield?
After a city builds a new public library, local reading test scores improve. City officials claim the library caused the improvement. What would strengthen or weaken this causal claim?

In a medical trial, patients receiving a new drug recover faster than those receiving a placebo. However, the patients receiving the drug also had more nurse visits. How does this affect the conclusion that the drug caused faster recovery?

A technology company introduces flexible working hours and observes increased productivity. What experiments could they design to determine if flexible hours actually caused the productivity increase?

Research shows that neighborhoods with more fast food restaurants have higher obesity rates. A health advocate argues for restricting fast food restaurants to reduce obesity. What causal reasoning issues should be considered before implementing this policy?

Students who participate in music programs tend to have higher math scores. A school board member proposes expanding music programs to improve math performance. What causal confounds should be considered before making this decision?

A political candidate notes that during her opponent's term in office, crime rates increased. She claims this proves her opponent's policies caused more crime. Explain the causal reasoning fallacy in this argument.

In a forest, scientists observe that areas with more birdsong have healthier vegetation. One researcher suggests playing recorded birdsong to improve plant health. What's problematic about this causal inference?

A study finds that people who meditate regularly report less stress. The researchers conclude meditation reduces stress. A critic argues this conclusion isn't warranted. Why might the critic be correct from a causal reasoning perspective?

Historical data shows that countries with higher chocolate consumption have more Nobel laureates per capita. What's wrong with concluding that eating chocolate increases a nation's likelihood of producing Nobel Prize winners?

A retail store changes its layout and sales increase the following month. The manager attributes the sales increase to the new layout. What alternative explanations might exist, and how could you test whether the layout actually caused the increase?

An online article claims that vaccinated children have higher rates of developmental disorders than unvaccinated children. Assuming this correlation is accurate, explain why this doesn't necessarily mean vaccines cause these disorders.

In a remote village, a new telecommunications tower was installed. Shortly after, several villagers developed headaches. The villagers blame the tower's radiation. Evaluate this causal claim and suggest how it could be properly investigated.

Countries with higher education spending tend to have citizens with longer lifespans. A politician argues that increasing education funding will make people live longer. What causal reasoning errors might be present in this argument?

A professor notices that students who sit in the front row earn higher grades. She concludes that sitting in the front causes better academic performance. What alternative causal explanations exist for this observation?

Every time a rooster crows, the sun rises shortly after. A child concludes that the rooster's crow causes the sun to rise. Using this example, explain the difference between correlation and causation.
A company's stock price drops after a negative news report is published. What factors would you need to consider before concluding that the news report caused the stock price drop?

After a river is cleaned up, local fish populations increase. Simultaneously, new fishing regulations are implemented. How would you determine which intervention had the greater causal effect on fish population recovery?

A social media platform changes its algorithm, and user engagement decreases. At the same time, a competitor launches a new feature. How could the platform determine whether its algorithm change caused the engagement drop?

A pharmaceutical company finds that patients taking their pain medication report more side effects than those taking a competitor's drug. What needs to be considered before concluding their medication causes more side effects?

Global temperatures and pirate population have both changed over the past 300 years. As pirate numbers decreased, global temperatures increased. Using this absurd correlation, explain why identifying spurious correlations is important for proper causal reasoning.

After implementing a four-day work week, a company observes improved employee satisfaction and productivity. The CEO wants to know if the four-day week caused these improvements. Design a study that would better establish causality in this scenario.
A fair six-sided die is rolled 10 times. What is the probability that the number 6 appears exactly twice in these 10 rolls?
In a class of 30 students, what is the probability that at least two students share the same birthday? Assume there are 365 days in a year and birthdays are distributed uniformly throughout the year.

You have two fair coins. One is a regular coin with heads and tails. The other is a biased coin that comes up heads 75% of the time. You randomly select one coin and flip it twice. Both flips come up heads. What is the probability that you selected the biased coin?
A bag contains 5 red balls, 3 green balls, and 2 blue balls. If you draw 3 balls at random without replacement, what is the probability of getting exactly 2 red balls and 1 green ball?

A test for a certain disease has a false positive rate of 2% and a false negative rate of 5%. If 1% of the population has this disease, what is the probability that a person who tests positive actually has the disease?
Three fair six-sided dice are rolled. What is the probability that the sum of the numbers shown is exactly 10?
A standard deck of 52 cards is shuffled. You draw cards one by one without replacement until you get an ace. What is the expected number of cards you will need to draw?
In a group of 5 people, each person randomly selects one of the other 4 people to give a gift to. What is the probability that at least one person receives no gifts?
A fair coin is flipped until either the pattern HHT (heads, heads, tails) or the pattern HTH (heads, tails, heads) appears. What is the probability that HHT appears before HTH?
Five cards are dealt from a standard 52-card deck. What is the probability of getting exactly two pair (e.g., two kings, two queens, and one other card)?

A jar contains 10 red marbles and 8 blue marbles. You draw marbles one at a time without replacement until you have drawn all marbles of the same color. What is the expected number of marbles you will draw?
Two players take turns flipping a fair coin. The first player who gets heads wins. If player A goes first, what is the probability that player A wins?
A bag contains 3 red balls and 2 white balls. You draw balls one by one without replacement. If the first ball is red, what is the probability that the third ball is also red?
In a room of n people, what is the probability that at least one person shares a birthday with you? Assume there are 365 days in a year and birthdays are distributed uniformly throughout the year.
You roll a fair six-sided die repeatedly and keep a running sum. What is the probability that you reach exactly 20 before exceeding 20?
A box contains 20 light bulbs, of which 4 are defective. If 6 bulbs are selected at random, what is the probability that at most 1 is defective?
Two players, A and B, take turns rolling a fair six-sided die. The first person to roll a 6 wins. If A goes first, what is the probability that B wins?

A multiple-choice test has 10 questions, each with 4 possible answers, only one of which is correct. A student guesses randomly on each question. What is the probability that the student gets at least 7 questions correct?

Three friends play a game where they each roll a fair six-sided die. The person with the highest unique roll wins. If there is no unique highest roll, they all roll again. What is the probability that the first player wins?

In a Bayesian network, event A has a prior probability of 0.3. Event B occurs with probability 0.8 if A occurs, and with probability 0.1 if A does not occur. If B is observed, what is the posterior probability of A given B?

A hunter has two rifles. The probability of hitting a target with the first rifle is 0.7, and with the second rifle is 0.4. The hunter randomly selects one of the rifles and fires at a target. Given that the shot hit the target, what is the probability that the hunter used the first rifle?
A casino game involves rolling two fair six-sided dice. You win $10 if the sum is 7, win $5 if the sum is 11, and lose $1 otherwise. What is the expected value of this game?
A biased coin comes up heads with probability p. You flip the coin n times and observe k heads. Using the maximum likelihood estimation, what is the estimated value of p?

You have 100 coins, and 99 of them are fair (with probability 0.5 of heads), but one of them is biased with probability 0.9 of heads. You pick a coin at random and flip it 10 times. You observe 9 heads and 1 tail. What is the probability that you picked the biased coin?

A lottery ticket has 6 numbers chosen from 1 to 49. The lottery draw also selects 6 numbers from 1 to 49. If you match all 6 numbers, you win the jackpot. What is the probability of winning the jackpot?
Two fair six-sided dice are rolled. Given that the sum of the two dice is at least 10, what is the probability that at least one of the dice shows a 6?
Five cards are dealt from a standard 52-card deck. What is the probability of getting a flush (all cards of the same suit) that is not a straight flush?

In a certain country, 45% of the population has blood type O, 40% has type A, 11% has type B, and 4% has type AB. A blood test correctly identifies the blood type with probability 0.95. If a test indicates a person has type O blood, what is the probability that they actually have type O blood?
A box contains 10 balls: 4 red, 3 blue, and 3 green. Five balls are drawn randomly without replacement. What is the probability that at least one ball of each color is drawn?
A random variable X follows a normal distribution with mean μ = 50 and standard deviation σ = 10. What is the probability that the value of X is between 45 and 60?

A city implemented a new highway to reduce traffic congestion. Initially, travel times decreased by 20%, but after 6 months, congestion was worse than before the highway was built. Explain this phenomenon using systems thinking concepts.

In a predator-prey ecosystem with wolves and rabbits, the wolf population was reduced by 50% through hunting. One year later, the rabbit population had decreased by 30% rather than increasing as expected. What systemic factors might explain this counterintuitive outcome?

A company implemented a bonus system tied to individual performance metrics. While individual productivity rose 15%, overall company performance decreased by 8%. Identify potential system-level explanations for this discrepancy.

A hospital reduced waiting times in the emergency department by adding more beds, but found that patient admission rates increased by 25% and overall costs rose significantly. Using systems thinking, analyze the unintended consequences of this intervention.

In a manufacturing system, quality inspections were increased at the final production stage, yet the number of defective products reaching customers increased. Explain how this could happen from a systems perspective.

A fishery management system introduced strict quotas on a certain fish species. Five years later, the overall marine ecosystem showed decreased biodiversity despite the target species recovering. What systems thinking concepts might explain this outcome?

A social media platform changed its algorithm to reduce the spread of misinformation. While directly false content decreased by 40%, overall user polarization increased. Using systems thinking, explain this apparent contradiction.
A city banned plastic bags to reduce environmental impact. Two years later, the overall plastic waste had increased by 5%. Identify possible system-level explanations for this unexpected outcome.

In a complex supply chain, one company implemented just-in-time inventory to reduce costs. While their costs decreased, their suppliers' costs increased by 35% and delivery reliability decreased. Explain this situation through a systems thinking lens.

A school system implemented standardized testing to improve education quality. Test scores improved by 25% over three years, but college readiness and critical thinking skills declined. What systems dynamics might explain these contradictory results?

A national healthcare system provided free preventive care services, expecting to reduce long-term costs. After five years, total healthcare spending had increased by 12%. Using systems thinking, identify possible explanations for this outcome.

Identify and explain three different types of feedback loops that might exist in an urban transportation system, and how they might interact to produce unexpected outcomes when new policies are implemented.

A company experiencing high employee turnover implemented higher salaries and better benefits. Six months later, turnover remained unchanged. Using systems archetypes, explain why this intervention might have failed to address the root problem.

In a water management system, engineers increased reservoir capacity by 30% to prevent flooding. During the next rainy season, downstream communities experienced 40% worse flooding. Explain this outcome using concepts of system boundaries and interconnections.

A social service agency implemented a new case management system to improve client outcomes. While the number of clients served increased by 50%, the average outcome quality decreased. What systems thinking principles could explain this result?

A retail chain centralized its purchasing decisions to improve efficiency. While procurement costs decreased by 20%, overall profitability decreased. Identify potential system-level issues that could cause this unexpected outcome.

An agricultural system introduced genetically modified crops resistant to certain pests. After three growing seasons, farmers were dealing with new types of pests that caused more damage than before. Analyze this situation using systems thinking.

In a criminal justice system, mandatory minimum sentences were implemented to deter crime. Ten years later, crime rates were unchanged but incarceration costs had tripled. Using systems thinking, explain why the intended deterrence effect might not have materialized.

A global supply chain optimized for efficiency experienced catastrophic failures during a minor disruption in one region. Explain the concept of 'robust yet fragile' systems and how it applies to this situation.

A financial market implemented circuit breakers to prevent extreme volatility. While catastrophic crashes decreased, overall market volatility increased by 15%. Using systems concepts, explain this phenomenon.

An ecosystem containing five species exhibits stable population levels for decades. When a sixth species is introduced, two of the original species go extinct within five years. Explain how this could happen using the concept of system stability and attractors.

A power grid experiences increasing frequency of small outages after implementing smart grid technology designed to prevent large outages. Using the concept of self-organized criticality, explain how this pattern might emerge.

A team-based organization structure was implemented to replace a hierarchical one. While communication improved, decision-making slowed significantly. Analyze this using the concept of system optimization versus sub-optimization.

A city implemented a universal basic income pilot program in one district. While poverty decreased there, it increased in adjacent districts. Explain this outcome using systems boundaries and displacement effects.

A company reduced its carbon emissions by 50% by outsourcing manufacturing. From a systems perspective, evaluate whether this represents true environmental improvement and what metrics would provide a more accurate assessment.

A social network implemented content moderation algorithms that successfully reduced harmful content by 70%. Subsequently, user engagement dropped by 35% and harmful content migrated to private groups. Using systems thinking, analyze why the intervention had limited effectiveness.

A healthcare system improved emergency response times by 40% but saw no improvement in patient survival rates. Identify potential system-level explanations for this disconnect between process improvement and outcome improvement.

A manufacturing company implemented a zero-defect quality program that successfully eliminated defects but resulted in a 25% increase in production costs and 15% decrease in innovation. Using systems thinking, analyze the tradeoffs in this system.

A housing market experienced rapid price increases after zoning restrictions were implemented to preserve neighborhood character. Within five years, the demographic composition of the area changed dramatically despite the preservation effort. Explain this outcome using systems concepts.

An online marketplace platform changed its recommendation algorithm to maximize short-term revenue. While immediate sales increased by 30%, customer retention decreased by 20% over the following year. Using systems thinking, explain the dynamic that might be occurring.
Design a system to help elderly people remember to take their medications without using smartphones or complex technology.
Create a method to determine if a watermelon is ripe without cutting it open or tapping it.
Develop a way to cross a 20-meter wide river with only two 10-meter planks of wood.
Propose a solution for reducing food waste in school cafeterias by at least 50%.
Design a system to collect rainwater in a desert community with minimal infrastructure.
Create a method to fairly divide a cake among 7 people when each person values different parts of the cake differently.
Develop a non-electronic communication system that could work over a distance of 5 kilometers.
Design a way to transport a raw egg safely from the roof of a 10-story building to the ground without using conventional packaging materials.
Create a solution to prevent ice cream from melting quickly on hot days without using refrigeration or insulation.
Develop a method to determine the height of a tall building using only a barometer, without measuring air pressure.
Design a traffic system for a busy intersection that doesn't use traffic lights, stop signs, or roundabouts.
Create a way to identify counterfeit currency without using specialized equipment or technology.
Develop a method to sort a large pile of mixed recycling (plastic, paper, metal) efficiently without modern sorting machines.
Design a system to reduce water usage in home showers by 40% without reducing shower time or water pressure.
Create a solution for urban noise pollution that doesn't involve soundproofing buildings or restricting activities.
Develop a method to keep track of time accurately without using clocks, watches, or electronic devices.
Design a way to cook a meal during a power outage without using gas, fire, or battery-powered devices.
Create a system to help people find their parked car in a large parking lot without using GPS or smartphone technology.
Develop a method to prevent shoplifting in a retail store without using security cameras or electronic tags.
Design a non-digital solution to help people who speak different languages communicate effectively in emergency situations.
Create a way to discourage people from using their phones during social gatherings without confiscating the devices.
Develop a method to transport water uphill without using electricity, motors, or pumps.
Design a system to encourage children to do their household chores willingly without offering monetary rewards.
Create a solution to reduce the amount of plastic packaging waste generated by grocery shopping.
Develop a way to keep your place in a book without using bookmarks, dog-earing pages, or electronic devices.
Design a method to teach mathematics to visual learners who struggle with traditional numerical approaches.
Create a system to reduce traffic congestion during rush hour without building new roads or implementing public transportation.
Develop a way to organize a community event that includes people of all ages, abilities, and backgrounds so everyone feels equally included.
Design a solution to prevent bicycle theft in urban areas without using locks, chains, or electronic tracking devices.
Create a method to keep your home cool during summer heat waves without using air conditioning or electric fans.

A researcher notices that patients who consume a diet high in blueberries show lower rates of cognitive decline. The researcher concludes that blueberries prevent cognitive decline. What is the main flaw in this reasoning, and how could the researcher design a better study to test this hypothesis?

A pharmaceutical company tests a new pain medication on 1000 patients with chronic back pain. They find that 60% report reduced pain compared to 40% in the placebo group. The p-value is 0.03. What conclusions can reasonably be drawn from this data, and what additional information would be needed to determine if the medication should be approved for general use?

A biologist is studying the effects of a pesticide on bee populations. In controlled environments, she observes a 30% reduction in hive productivity when the pesticide is present. However, when conducting field studies, no significant difference is observed. Propose three possible explanations for this discrepancy and describe how you would test each explanation.

Scientists notice that in regions with higher chocolate consumption, there are lower rates of heart disease. Based on this observation, what are three different hypotheses that could explain this correlation, and how would you design experiments to distinguish between them?

A new teaching method is implemented in 10 schools, and test scores improve by an average of 15%. The department of education wants to implement this method nationwide. What confounding variables might explain the improvement besides the teaching method itself? How would you design a study to control for these variables?

A researcher claims to have developed a plant fertilizer that increases crop yield by 25%. They tested it on 100 corn plants in a greenhouse, comparing it to 100 plants without the fertilizer. Identify three limitations of this study design and propose improvements that would provide more convincing evidence of the fertilizer's effectiveness.

An ecologist is studying butterfly migration patterns and notices that in years with higher-than-average rainfall, butterflies tend to migrate earlier. Describe how you would design a controlled experiment to test whether rainfall directly affects migration timing or if other factors are involved.

A medical researcher observes that patients who sleep less than 6 hours per night have higher rates of heart disease. What are the possible causal relationships between sleep and heart disease? Outline a research program that could distinguish between these possibilities.

Three different teams of scientists studying climate change have produced models predicting temperature increases of 1.5°C, 2.7°C, and 4.1°C respectively by 2100. What factors might explain these differences, and how should policymakers evaluate these competing predictions?

A psychologist claims that listening to classical music improves mathematical ability. The study involved 50 university students who listened to Mozart for 10 minutes before taking a math test, and their scores were compared to their performance on a similar test without music. Critically evaluate this experimental design and suggest improvements.

Scientists observe that a previously unknown virus is present in 80% of patients with a rare neurological disorder, but only in 5% of the general population. What are the possible explanations for this association, and what studies would you conduct to determine if the virus causes the disorder?

A study finds that children who play violent video games show more aggressive behavior than those who don't. The researchers conclude that violent games cause aggression. Identify possible alternative explanations for this finding and explain what kind of study would better establish causation.

An agricultural scientist wants to determine if a new irrigation system conserves water while maintaining crop yields. Describe a controlled experimental design that would provide strong evidence about the effectiveness of the new system compared to traditional irrigation methods.

A physicist observes an unexpected pattern in particle collision data that doesn't match current theoretical predictions. Outline the process this physicist should follow to determine whether this represents a new discovery or an experimental error.

A new archaeological finding suggests humans arrived in North America 5,000 years earlier than previously thought. The evidence consists of stone tools and carbon-dated organic material. What questions should be asked about this evidence before accepting this new timeline, and what additional evidence would strengthen or weaken this claim?

Researchers observe that neighborhoods with more trees have lower crime rates. They propose planting trees in high-crime areas to reduce crime. Evaluate this proposal, considering alternative explanations for the correlation and how one might test the causal relationship.

A marine biologist notices that coral reefs near populated islands show more bleaching than reefs near uninhabited islands. Outline a research plan to determine whether human activity is causing the increased bleaching, and if so, which specific activities are most harmful.

A study reports that a specific genetic variant is associated with increased intelligence. The variant is found in 15% of the studied population and correlates with an average 5-point increase in IQ scores. What limitations should be considered when interpreting these results, and what follow-up studies would be appropriate?

A nutritionist conducts a study where 200 participants follow either a low-carb or low-fat diet for six months. The low-carb group loses an average of 12 pounds, while the low-fat group loses an average of 8 pounds. What factors beyond the diet composition might explain this difference, and how could the study design be improved?

Two pharmaceutical companies produce vaccines for the same virus. Company A reports 95% efficacy based on a trial with 40,000 participants across 5 countries. Company B reports 89% efficacy based on a trial with 20,000 participants in one country. How should public health officials evaluate these results when deciding which vaccine to purchase?

A geologist hypothesizes that a certain rock formation was created by ancient volcanic activity. What types of evidence would support or refute this hypothesis, and how could modern analytical techniques be applied to test it?

An astronomer detects an unusual radio signal that appears to be coming from a nearby star system. The signal does not match known natural phenomena. Describe the process of scientific investigation that should be followed before concluding that this represents evidence of extraterrestrial intelligence.

A city implements a new traffic management system and observes a 20% reduction in average commute times over the following month. What variables might confound this result, and how could you design a study to determine the actual impact of the new system?

Paleontologists discover fossilized microorganisms in Martian rock samples that resemble ancient Earth bacteria. What sequence of tests and analyses would be necessary to determine whether these represent evidence of past life on Mars versus contamination or non-biological structures?

A researcher develops a hypothesis that exposure to a specific frequency of sound waves can improve memory consolidation during sleep. Design an experimental protocol to test this hypothesis, including appropriate controls and measurements.

Scientists observe that areas with high air pollution have higher rates of respiratory diseases. They want to determine if different types of particulate matter (PM2.5, PM10, etc.) have different health impacts. Design a study that could differentiate the effects of various pollutants while controlling for socioeconomic and other environmental factors.

A physicist proposes a modification to Einstein's theory of general relativity that would explain certain astronomical observations without invoking dark matter. What observational or experimental evidence would be required to support this new theory over the standard model?

A study finds that people who meditate regularly have different brain activity patterns than non-meditators. The researchers conclude that meditation changes brain function. What are the limitations of this conclusion, and how could researchers better establish whether meditation causes these brain changes?

An economist notices that countries with higher chocolate consumption have more Nobel Prize winners per capita. Assuming this correlation is accurate, explain why concluding that chocolate consumption causes Nobel Prize achievement would be problematic. What alternative explanations exist, and how might they be tested?

A conservation biologist wants to determine whether a captive breeding program for an endangered bird species will be successful if implemented. What preliminary research should be conducted, what metrics would indicate success, and how should the program be designed to test its effectiveness while maximizing conservation outcomes?
